"Ancient superpower. Cradle of law and math. "

The name Babylon comes from Bāb-ili, meaning "Gate of the Gods" in Akkadian.
It was a city where mud bricks built empires, and clay tablets stored the world’s first written laws.

Most know Babylon for its Hanging Gardens—one of the Seven Wonders—though no records prove they existed.
Less known: its base-60 math system, still used today for time (60 seconds, 60 minutes) and circles (360 degrees).
The Code of Hammurabi (1754 BCE), carved in stone, listed 282 laws—like "an eye for an eye"—but also set wages, debts, and even doctor fees.
Babylon’s astronomers tracked Jupiter’s path in 7th century BCE, predicting eclipses centuries before telescopes.
Its downfall?
Persian king Cyrus captured the city in 539 BCE without a fight—legend says Babylon’s priests opened the gates, tired of their own ruler.

Three related subjects are cuneiform writing, Mesopotamian ziggurats, and Persian Empire’s rise.
